text:
Hello, *Goal*: test a pure Julia package (that I am currently developing on my own pc) on a computing server. 
The server has Julia installed, with its /.julia folder containing only a /.julia/logs subfolder. 

*Question*: Is copying the (possibly very large) /.julia folder from my own pc to the server enough to get this working?

Thank you!

elements.text:
: test a pure Julia package (that I am currently developing on my own pc) on a computing server. 
The server has Julia installed, with its /.julia folder containing only a /.julia/logs subfolder.

: Is copying the (possibly very large) /.julia folder from my own pc to the server enough to get this working?

Thank you!

text: Both Linux, but different numbers of processors/...

elements.text: Both Linux, but different numbers of processors/...

text: Linux isn't an architecture but an operating system. `x86_64` or `powerpc64le` are architectures

elements.text: Linux isn't an architecture but an operating system.

text:
Sorry and thank you :wink:
Yes, the same architecture.

in principle it might work.  I'd recommend deleting the `.julia/compiled` directory on the server after you copy the entire `.julia` folder, to make sure those files are properly regenerated for the new machine

directory on the server after you copy the entire
folder, to make sure those files are properly regenerated for the new machine
